title: Nuclear reactions - ratio of times for decay

content.question: A sample of unstable nuclei has <math alttext="N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>N</mi></math> nuclei at time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. There are <math alttext="the fraction N over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>N</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> original nuclei remaining after time <math alttext="t sub one half" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mfrac bevelled="true"><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></msub></math>. There are <math alttext="the fraction N over 8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>N</mi><mn>8</mn></mfrac></math> original nuclei remaining after <math alttext="t sub one eighth" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mfrac bevelled="true"><mn>1</mn><mn>8</mn></mfrac></msub></math>. What is the ratio <math alttext="the fraction with numerator t sub one eighth, and denominator t sub one half" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><msub><mi>t</mi><mfrac bevelled="true"><mn>1</mn><mn>8</mn></mfrac></msub><msub><mi>t</mi><mfrac bevelled="true"><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></msub></mfrac></math>?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
